subject: Re: [junit] How to automate the testcases!

messageBody:
On 2002-08-15 at 16:13 Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>> I was interested about the idea that JUnit might not be the best
>> tool for testing negative test cases.
>
>To make sure that we are talking about the same subject, I define
'negative
>testing' as making sure that the software (library in our case) is not
>doing
>what it is not supposed to do. In other words, that your system can
handle
>incorrect or inappropriate information. Examples are:
>
>- calling a method with wrong arguments (null, boundaries...)

Reflection can generally make this easier to do. JTest also appears to
do a good job at checking whether boundary values lead to unhandled
exceptions.

>- wrong type of String (numeric instead of text, wrong date format...)

Boo! The problem is that the code is not OO. Where are the number and
date objects that create themselves from string representations? This
is not a terribly difficult thing to write nor to test. :)

>- partial initialization of members

This may be a design problem: if I can exit a constructor without a
valid object, then maybe the constructor needs to do more or require
more of me.

>- methods called in no particular order (may reveal unstable state)

Indeed, this is tricky... this points to another design issue and is
not necessarily a simple issue to solve. The answer for the moment is
to have as little of this as possible. If you find you have to test it
often, then you have too much of it.

>the problem with negative testing is that it's endless. It's hard to
test
>what
>a system can do but even harder to test what it can't.

So you have a choice: either be like Ron and code to the main line, or
be clear about what happens when your class' clients are sloppy. You
may find a way to eliminate the opportunity to be sloppy, which is
usually best...

>It's possible to use JUnit to write negative tests (like testing
>exceptions)
>but if you have 1,000 classes and you want to test that each method of
>every
>class handles 'null' arguments correctly... well it's going to take a
>while.

Not with reflection... as long as you always handle the "null" argument
the same way, it's no worse than scanning all the classes in a source
path and iterating... I've never done it, but I wouldn't think it would
be that difficult. Annoying, perhaps; but you'd only have to do it
once.
